noun.description: The period of darkness in each twenty-four hours; the time from sunset to sunrise.
examples: the office door is always locked at night

noun.description: The period of time between afternoon and bedtime; an evening.
examples: he was not allowed to go out on weekday nights
investments that won't keep us awake nights with worry

phrases: As the words flowed night and day, we felt we were giving voice to a new generation of rebels.
During the past week, the people involved in the project have worked night and day to have the centre ready for the opening.
Put simply, Scotland has to watch and listen, night and day, to every little thing that affects English sporting teams.
Would it be better if the city were dependent for its wealth on huge factories belching out pollution night and day?
origin: Old English neaht, niht, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch nacht and German Nacht, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin nox and Greek nux.
